abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Fortant de France's 1998 white merlot, available at Manhattan shops; photo (M)

block.p: Take the idea of white zinfandel, at best a bimbo of a wine, give it a Ph.D. during winemaking in Languedoc, and you've got Fortant de France's sophisticated '98 white merlot.

This warm-weather refresher with a grapefruity, almost-quinine nip -- the stylish equivalent of a sleek Tanqueray gin and tonic -- can be perfect with seafood, as a brunch wine or, under a peppermint-striped tent, as a crowd-pleasing aperitif. A sunlight-refracting salmon-coral in color, in a transparent carafe it could replace a floral centerpiece.
Take the idea of white zinfandel, at best a bimbo of a wine, give it a Ph.D. during winemaking in Languedoc, and you've got Fortant de France's sophisticated '98 white merlot.

This warm-weather refresher with a grapefruity, almost-quinine nip -- the stylish equivalent of a sleek Tanqueray gin and tonic -- can be perfect with seafood, as a brunch wine or, under a peppermint-striped tent, as a crowd-pleasing aperitif. A sunlight-refracting salmon-coral in color, in a transparent carafe it could replace a floral centerpiece.

The brainchild of the producer Robert Skalli, who almost singlehandedly invented the wine's southern appellation, Vins de Pays d'Oc, this casual bone-dry white merlot is a cornucopia of surprises: a tea-rose bouquet, chiffon weight, fruit-compote complexity with daubs of anise, kitchen-garden herbs, and a piquant and seemingly endless aftertaste.

Icy cold refrigeration numbs the wine, to its detriment, and your money's; drink it cool, and the intricacies unfold (it's even lovely, in an unorthodox way, when warm). In the end, it's a bauble -- a serious bauble -- that for some will recall the summer pleasures of a Tavel rose. Don't knock it back; sip it languidly, filling the palate fully.

A bottle costs $6 at East Village Wines, 138 First Avenue (St. Marks Place), and $8 at New Ehrlich's, 222 Amsterdam Avenue (West 70th Street), in Manhattan; $7 at Aida's World of Liquors, 2626 Hylan Boulevard (Beach Street), in New Dorp, Staten Island.
